results.title: DreamWorks: in conversation with Bill Damaschke
results.creator_credit: Kim Montgomery, Shelley Matulick and ACMI

video_links.name: DreamWorks: in conversation with Bill Damaschke

results.brief_description:
Go behind the scenes of DreamWorks Animation’s incredible success story with one of the key architects of its amazing 20-year journey - Chief Creative Officer Bill Damaschke.
From overseeing the creative production and development processes for the studio’s feature projects, to shaping the creative teams behind each project and growing the studio’s creative talent pool, Damaschke has played an integral role in bringing the DreamWorks worlds to the big screen.
Damaschke joined DreamWorks in 1995 and served as a producer and executive producer on a number of the studio’s feature films before being named Head of Creative Production in 1999, Head of Creative Production and Development in 2005 and Co-President of Production for Feature Animation and President of Live Theatricals in 2007.
During his tenure at DreamWorks Animation, Damaschke has overseen the release of a range of key DreamWorks titles, from the Academy Award-winning blockbuster ‘Shrek’ in 2001 through to the highly anticipated ‘How to Train Your Dragon 2’.
In Australia to celebrate the opening of the ‘DreamWorks Animation: The Exhibition’, Damaschke joined us for this one off event to discuss his exceptional creative career, his central role in DreamWorks Animation’s future releases, and his insights into the creative hub of one of the world’s most influential animation studios.
Hosted by Walkley Award winning journalist, author, broadcaster and presenter of ABC News Breakfast Virginia Trioli.

results.title: DreamWorks: in conversation with Jeffrey Katzenberg
results.creator_credit: Kim Montgomery, Shelley Matulick and ACMI

video_links.name: DreamWorks: in conversation with Jeffrey Katzenberg

results.brief_description:
CEO and co-founder of DreamWorks speaks exclusively about creating, leading and inspiring the world’s largest animation studio in this rare one-off Australian event. A must-see for filmmakers, animators, fans and would-be moguls of tomorrow, hosted by Channel 10’s Executive General Manager, Russel Howcroft (best known as The Gruen Transfer’s advertising media personality).
Katzenberg began his career at Paramount Pictures before moving to Walt Disney Pictures where he is credited with turning the ailing animation studio around. Under his management, Disney produced some of their most critically acclaimed and highest grossing features to date, including ‘The Little Mermaid’ and ‘The Lion King’. He also secured a successful partnership with Pixar Studios and helped bring Miramax Films to Disney. Katzenberg eventually joined forces with Steven Spielberg and David Geffen to start DreamWorks SKG.
Under Katzenberg’s leadership, DreamWorks has become the largest animation studio in the world releasing 28 animated feature films, which have enjoyed both critical and commercial success, earning nine Academy Award nominations, twice winning Best Animated Feature.
In 2013, Katzenberg was awarded the prestigious Jean Hersholt Humanitarian Award by the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences for his outstanding contributions to humanitarian causes.
Together with his wife Marilyn, Katzenberg provides support and leads fundraising efforts focused predominately on healthcare, education, the arts and the environment.

Proudly supported by the United States Consulate General Melbourne.

results.title: Spectacle Director Showcase: Leo Baker
results.creator_credit: Kim Montgomery, Shelley Matulick, Mike Kenneally, Richard Greenhalgh and ACMI
results.brief_description: Celebrated animator Leo Baker discusses working with Australian band ‘Children Collide’ to create a hybrid live-action and animation video for their song ‘Praying for Sunshine’. Aside from making music videos, Baker was also one of the lead animators on the Oscar-winning screen adaptation of Shaun Tan’s acclaimed ‘The Lost Thing’.

results.title: Spectacle Director Showcase: Natasha Pincus
results.creator_credit: Kim Montgomery, Shelley Matulick, Mike Kenneally and ACMI
results.brief_description:
Natasha Pincus is a multi award winning Australian music video director and producer and has won the ARIA award for Best Music Video two years in a row. Her stop motion animation video for Gotye’s ‘Somebody That I Used to Know’ has had a staggering 420 million views. Natasha talks about getting her first big break making a music video for Paul Kelly.

Created as part of “Spectacle : The Music Video Exhibition” 26 September 2013 - 23 February 2014. ACMI Digital Programs worked with Exhibitions to interview five Australian directors featured in the exhibition about the art and techniques of music video production.

results.title: Custom MAME arcade machine
results.brief_description: One way to preserve videogames is emulation, which recreates retro hardware and software on modern machines. MAME (Multiple Arcade Machine Emulator) is one of the most important emulation tools.
results.description:
It’s not that easy to keep videogames running. Technology evolves at a rapid pace, including software and hardware, making some of the most iconic games from the past unplayable on today’s technology. Not to mention all the parts and programs used in videogames that are long obsolete and no longer supported. In the past fifty years, countless games have been lost.

But it’s not all bad. One of the most important tools to preserve videogames is emulation, which recreates the hardware and software needed to run games on modern machines.

MAME, or Multiple Arcade Machine Emulator, is one of the most well-known and important emulation tools. It recreates the inner workings of thousands of arcade machines, letting players in the present a chance to play the best games of the past.
description_for_label:

MAME, or Multiple Arcade Machine Emulator, is one of the most well-known and important emulation tools. It recreates the inner workings of thousands of arcade machines, letting players in the present a chance to play the best games of the past.

results.title: Tripoli Melbourne & Me!
results.creator_credit: Dania Dabliz, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: Dania Dabliz’s life in Tripoli was full of fun, friends and parties. When she migrated to Melbourne she wondered if she would find the same things again?

results.title: Faces
results.brief_description:
Sue Ford’s experimental film “Faces” consists of portraits of the artist and her friends and acquaintances. Ford filmed each subject for roughly 25 seconds, using a wind-up Bolex camera that framed their faces in close-up. Variously self-conscious, serious, amused and distracted, the camera captures every small gesture, expression and flicker of emotion on the person’s face. The result is an examination of portraiture and the performance of identity, demonstrating the artist’s interest in using the camera to capture reality, time and change.

Participants in the film include artists Micky Allan, Bonita Ely and Paul Reed, among others.
results.description:

Variously self-conscious, serious, nonchalant, curious, amused and distracted, the camera captures every small gesture, expression and flicker of emotion on the person’s face. The result is an examination of portraiture and the performance of identity, demonstrating the artist’s interest in using the camera to capture reality, time and change.

Participants in the film include artists Micky Allan, Bonita Ely and Paul Reed, among others.

results.title: Free Willy 2: the adventure home
results.creator_credit: Dwight Little, Jennie Lew-Tugend, Lauren Shuler, Donner Productions and Shuler-Donner
results.brief_description: Jesse is reunited with his Orca friend Willy who has rejoined his family in the wild. Willy becomes trapped by an oil spill fire and Jesse is determined to rescue Willy even if it means risking his own life. Action packed adventure with superb photography, this is a film to be shared by all the family and lovers of whales.
